windows.symptom: photo size        hi what should I do when I move a photo to lockscreen it zooms up in size I've tried to change settings but it stay's on the zoom size ?
solutions: Hi DAVIDINKPEN, My name is Marc, thanks for participating in the Microsoft Community, I'm an Independent Advisor and I'll be glad to help you today.Try to adjust the image as follows, this I did for the photos that I use in the background, lock screen, and adjusts it according to the size of my screen.Press Windows Start key >> Write: Photo >> Once the application is loaded, select the image >> Click on crop (Up on your screen), then on the right of the screen >> Click on Aspect Ratio Menu >> Select: Lockscreen or Widescreen, save and then test if it fits your need. Usually, this is the size according to the screen, and the best visual state that can adapt that image.Let me know if you have something else that I can help you with, I'd be happy to help.Happy Holidays Regards, Marc M.

windows.symptom: Windows 10 - BSOD ""a required device isn't connected or can't be accessed 0xc00000f" during update. Repeating...        Hi,Windows is trying to install latest updates (I think it's 1903/1909), but during the installation process after the second or third reboot I get this dreaded BSOD. I can repair the machine using a Restore Point, but the problem returns the next time the Update installs. So, I must find out the root cause and fix it before the next iteration of the Update runs.I've booted the computer from a Recovery Drive USB, and am requesting to figure out the best way to determine why the BSOD is happening and how to fix it permanently. I appreciate any assistance this forum can provide.Thanks,Ivan
solutions: Hello! I am an Independent Advisor, I would love to help you out! Can you upload the dump files from the bluescreen then I may be able to look further into the root cause potentially.The dmp files should be located here: C:\windows\Minidump Zip any files and upload them to onedrive and link the download here. From there I can look at it further.
Hi Thagstrom,The Minidump folder is empty. :(Ivan

When the update runs do you have all USB devices unplugged? If not, I would suggest that as a first step, as sometimes usb devices have been known to cause problems.You could also pause the updates for up to 35 days. This would give time where the next iteration of updates should release and hopefully the issue is resolved in that update.You could also try to go through the guided walk through for fixing windows update errors. It is a great resource that will take you step by step in order to fix any issues with windows update.Here is the link: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/10164/... I hope this helps!

Hi,As for your suggestions:1. During the Update, the only USB device attached is my wireless mouse. I could remove it, but frankly I very much doubt this is the problem.2. As I'm currently on Release 1809, I don't have an option to delay the Update for 35 days.3. I checked all of the steps in the guided walkthrough and got all of the way to the last step. (reinstall Windows).I ran the SetupDiag utility and nothing is being reported.I was hoping to get some insight on how to determine the root cause for the particular BSOD error that I am getting. I've had some previous issues with Windows Update on this machine, but have never seen this particular BSOD before. Can I split up the Update into smaller steps so that I can pinpoint the specific step that causes the BSOD? Where are the tracing/logging tools??I'm considering a complete reinstall of Windows, but this is a real pain that is a last resort. There are years of experiences and updates in this computer, and it will take me several days to put it back together. (Not to mention how annoyed my wife will be if I have to do this... )Thanks again,Ivan

Hi Ivan, please run chkdsk c: /r /scan command - will it find any errors? Check system journal (Event Viewer) for possible errors, especially Kernel-Power errors. DistributedCOM errors should be ignored.

Hi,Back on this after a Christmas break. I had adjusted my Wifi connection be metered in an attempt to delay the automated system updates. This appeared to work for a few days, until earlier today, when my machine wouldn't boot after another failed upgrade.Igor, as for your suggestions, I ran chkdsk with no errors. Event Viewer displayed multiple Critical Kernel-Power errors. These seem to coincide with the failed upgrades. Question I have is whether these are the source of the problem, or simply result after I am forced to power cycle the computer so I can boot to the USB drive in order to recover using the Restore Point?Below are the details from the most recent Kernel-Power event. Thanks for your time.IvanLog Name:      SystemSource:        Microsoft-Windows-Kernel-PowerDate:          2019-12-28 3:04:46 PMEvent ID:      41Task Category: (63)Level:         CriticalKeywords:      (70368744177664),(2)User:          SYSTEMComputer:      MEWS_ToshibaDescription:The system has rebooted without cleanly shutting down first. This error could be caused if the system stopped responding, crashed, or lost power unexpectedly.Event Xml:<Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event">  <System>    <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Kernel-Power" Guid="{331c3b3a-2005-44c2-ac5e-77220c37d6b4}" />    <EventID>41</EventID>    <Version>6</Version>    <Level>1</Level>    <Task>63</Task>    <Opcode>0</Opcode>    <Keywords>0x8000400000000002</Keywords>    <TimeCreated SystemTime="2019-12-28T20:04:46.321797300Z" />    <EventRecordID>27318</EventRecordID>    <Correlation />    <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="8" />    <Channel>System</Channel>    <Computer>MEWS_Toshiba</Computer>    <Security UserID="S-1-5-18" />  </System>  <EventData>    <Data Name="BugcheckCode">0</Data>    <Data Name="BugcheckParameter1">0x0</Data>    <Data Name="BugcheckParameter2">0x0</Data>    <Data Name="BugcheckParameter3">0x0</Data>    <Data Name="BugcheckParameter4">0x0</Data>    <Data Name="SleepInProgress">4</Data>    <Data Name="PowerButtonTimestamp">132220367682727788</Data>    <Data Name="BootAppStatus">0</Data>    <Data Name="Checkpoint">9</Data>    <Data Name="ConnectedStandbyInProgress">false</Data>    <Data Name="SystemSleepTransitionsToOn">15</Data>    <Data Name="CsEntryScenarioInstanceId">0</Data>    <Data Name="BugcheckInfoFromEFI">false</Data>    <Data Name="CheckpointStatus">0</Data>  </EventData></Event>

Hi all,In case anyone is following this thread, here's an update. I've had problems with Windows Updates on this Toshiba Satellite P55T laptop in the past. These have usually been related to the AMD Radeon M9 GPU. This GPU has been a disaster from the beginning, and had been overheating regularly, resulting in system crashes. Attempts to update the AMD drivers resulted in more crashes. So I had disabled the GPU in Windows Device Manager. The result was a more stable computer during regular use. But whenever Windows Home attempted to install an Update, all hell would break loose because the update would crash when it detected the disabled GPU and tried to update the drivers.Using the Microsoft "SetupDiag" tool, I was able to determine that the installation for 1903/1909 was logging an error for a driver update on the Radeon. It was not clear from the SetupDiag log whether this issue was in fact the root cause of the Update  crash / BSOD, but decided to figure out a way around it and see what happens. I discovered the "Policy Plus" tool, which provides Group Policy functions that are not included in Windows 10 Home. I used Policy Plus to edit the system to disable driver updates on the Radeon system devices. A good procedure is here: https://www.howtogeek.com/263851/how-to-prevent-windows-from-automatically-updating-specific-drivers/I'm pleased to report that I was then able to successfully install the Updates from a USB drive. Since I cannot physically remove this crappy AMD Radeon GPU, as long as I have this laptop I'll have to expect problems related to Windows Updates.Thanks to anyone who looked at this for me.Ivan

windows.symptom: Task manager not showing ram speed or details.        Ram speed details not showing on right side like it should.
solutions: What OS build are you on?  Hit the Windows key, type winver, hit Enter.Or Windows key+r, winver, OK

Hi D1VYBC My name is Andre Da Costa; an Independent Consultant, Windows Insider MVP and Windows & Devices for IT MVP. I'm here to help you with your problem.Can you check if you are able to get the speed through command prompt? Click Start, type: CMD Right click CMD Click Run as administrator Type the following command then hit Enter: wmic memorychip get speed You might also want to check the memory for errors: https://www.groovypost.com/howto/use-the-memory...Information in the above link is sourced from a trusted Microsoft MVP blog.
1903Thank you.
There is no errors, this happened after a fresh install. I can see the speed via the cmd command you said.

Since you just installed Windows 10, I recommend you check for the latest updates then install them.Click Start > Settings > Update & security > Windows Update > Check for updates Download and install any pending updates Restart your computer
Hey Andre, I'm running all the latests updates, drivers, and chipsets.

If its a desktop... Try resetting your BIOS defaults: https://www.groovypost.com/howto/reset-pc-bios-...If that does not work and you have a desktop computer... Power down Unplug it Open the system unit Remove the CMOS CR-2032 chip Plug it in, start the machine, wait 10 seconds Power down, unplug it, reinstall the CMOS CR-2032 chip Plug it in again, power up If that does not work, I recommend you try the repair upgrade. Download the Media Creation Tool Now http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=691209Right click the MediaCreationTool.exe file then click Run as administrator. Accept the End User License Agreement: Select the option Upgrade this PC now if you want to upgrade right away, Click Next Accept the End User License Agreement. Wait while Windows 10 setup does one final check to ensure your system is ready. Windows 10 setup will check if you have enough disk space. Please note, you have the option of choosing what you would like to keep, which includes personal files, apps and settings.If you want to perform a new install or just keep your files click Change what to keep. Once you have chosen the desired options, click Install to begin.This will be your screen for a little while. During the installation, your computer will restart several times.After the first restart, Windows 10 setup will resume. You will notice the setup experience has once again been refined from the previous animated circle. This will be your screen for a while. When complete, Windows 10 setup will restart automatically.Sign into your account. Wait while Windows 10 completes application updates and post setup tasks. That’s it, the Windows 10 Feature Update is installed.You can check Windows Update for latest updates, click Start > Settings > Update & security > Windows Update > Check for Updates.How to prepare your computer before upgrading? Although updating to Windows 10 version 1903 is a relatively simple process, similar to a repair upgrade; users should perform some basic pre-requisites before initiating the upgrade.If you are finding it difficult to carry out some of the steps described below, please review detailed instructions how to perform them:https://www.groovypost.com/howto/prepare-comput...Information in the above link is sourced from a trusted Microsoft MVP blog.
That is the Version not the OS Build.
Hi D1VYBC Click your Start Button, type winver and hit Enter On the resulting dialog, what Version No. and build No. of Windows 10 are you running?
18362.239Thank you.

WiFi signal is very weak after last Windows Update        The WiFi on my windows 10 machine is 0-1 bar at all times after installing the most recent windows update.  All other devices in my home (even ones farther away from the router) have 4-5 bars.  I ran a speed test and I only get 40-45 MBPS download speeds, where as my other devices get 100-200 MBPS.The update seems to be the problem.  How can I fix this?
solutions: I should also note that prior to the Windows update, my WiFi signal on the Windows 10 machine was excellent and also was getting over 100 MBPS.

Hi RPJpeg My name is Jon and I am an independent technical adviser. Sorry to hear you are experiencing issues and I would really like to help you find a resolution.Try rolling back your Wi-Fi driver Open Start. Search for Device Manager and click the top result to open the experience. Expand Network Adapters. Right-click the device, and select the Properties option. Click the Driver tab. Click the Roll Back Driver button. Select a reason why you're rolling back (you can select any option). Click the Yes button to confirm. Restart your computer. Hope this helps.

Hi RPJpeg,try to restore the network first:Settings> Network and Internet> Status.Click Network Reset on the right side, follow the instructions and read the notes.If it does not solve, temporarily uninstall any third party firewall / antivirus and try again.If the problem persists, uninstall any VPN software, network optimization software (SmartByte, Killer Network Manager, Rivet Dynamic Bandwidth Management etc.). other optimization software or third-party programs for automatic driver management.Then try to run and keep a clean boot:https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/929135/how-to-perform-a-clean-boot-in-windows

windows.symptom: Windows 10 Activation        Hello!My father has recently purchased a Toshiba Windows laptop, but as it did not have Windows installed on it, I took the liberty to install it myself.The previous user had installed an operating system called "SimPC", but due to the Windows 10 key and logo, I concluded that it was originally a windows laptop.Shortly after installing Windows on this new Computer, I wiped his old Windows Computer and removed it off of his microsoft account. But despite the fact that he has digital signage and now only the new computer on his windows account, it is telling me that I still need to "Activate Windows" on the new computer.Is there something I am doing wrong? Or do I need to purchase a new license key?Thanks!
solutions: If the original PC had an OEM license (Windows came pre-installed) then it cannot be transferred to another PC.If the license was retail (bought separately from the PC) then it can be transferred.

Using my Microsoft account to log into my Win10, still experience pop-ups asking for admin confirmation when installing software        Hi all.I've got my laptop freshly reinstalled and the user "user" has been the first entered (local one, I presume). So this is THE admin user.Now I set up my account on my laptop by logging in with my Microsoft account. Every time I install some software, or execute some "shielded" (admin) operation, I get a pop-up asking for admin "user" password.Is there any way I can get rid of it and use only my Microsoft account as THE admin on my laptop?Thanks,F.
solutions: Hi Boniforti Yes, you can have the Microsoft account as a member of the administrators group. (warning - it seems that in windows 10 it is possible to remove admin privileges from all accounts, Make sure you keep at least one Admin account)click start and type netplwiz press enter you will see a list of the users, microsoft accounts will show the email address as the username.select the account you wish to change and select properties on the group membership tab select administrator and click OK this will prevent the need to enter an administrator password, but will not prevent the user account control popup, although you only need to accept or dismiss itto prevent UAC (not recommended) click start, type UAC and select "change user account control settings" from the resultsyou can set it to "never notify". this of course means that if something else is trying to make changes to your computer you may not be warned.

solutions: Hello! My name is Marco, I am an Independent Advisor. I will do my best to help you.Try to do a scan with these 2 free and powerful software, you may have spyware that slows down your computerAdwCleaner : https://www.malwarebytes.com/adwcleaner/Malwarebytes : https://malwarebytes.com/Otherwise, we will try something else. :) _________________________________________________ Note: This is a non-Microsoft website. The page appears to be providing accurate, safe information. Watch out for ads on the site that may advertise products frequently classified as a PUP (Potentially Unwanted Products). Thoroughly research any product advertised on the site before you decide to download and install it.

why is my windows 10 too slow to restart Slow starts are attributable to one of three causes. In no particular order, they are:1- Too many programs trying to start alongside Windows.One way to begin diagnosing this is to open Task Manager and turn to the Startup tab. Do you need all those programs to start with Windows?2- Malware infectionSome strains of malware will do much of their work as the computer is starting.3- Incorrect configuration changePeople make all kinds of mistakes when they change their computer's settings, usually by following bad advice. Sometimes an improper change might affect how the computer starts.

windows.symptom: camera problem        when joining a meeting on zoom I was asked if I want to join with video to which I clicked yes, and when my photo came up I was upside down. can anyone help?
solutions: Hi Donna My name is Jon and I am an independent technical adviser. Sorry to hear you are experiencing issues and I would really like to help you find a resolution.How to rotate your camera before a meeting Log in to the Zoom client. Click your profile picture then click Settings. Click the Video tab. Hover over the preview of your camera. Click Rotate 90° until your camera is rotated correctly. How to rotate your camera while in a meeting Click the arrow next to Stop Video. Choose Video Settings. Hover over the preview of your camera. Click Rotate 90° until your camera is rotated correctly. Hope this helps.

Update via Media creation tool (direct update and with USB stick).My actual version is 1803 Build 17134.1099Further information:- A lot of colleagues have the same same issue using 1803- We use McAfee Endpoint Security (I don't have the power to deactivate this)- We use Cb defense (I don't have the power to deactivate this)If you need any log files, just ask for it.Thanks for your help.
solutions: Hi Henning. I'm Greg, an installation specialist, 10 year Windows MVP, and Volunteer Guardian Moderator here to help you.After ten years daily in forums, usually when someone says McAfee we've found the problem, and two security suites is almost a guaranteed conflict. So there's that.Go over these steps for overcoming Version Upgrade problems: http://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wiki... But unless you can disable those suspects it is going to be doubtful. What does always work is a Clean Install following the illustrated steps in this link which include everything that works best in Windows 10:http://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wiki... I hope this helps. Feel free to ask back any questions and keep me posted. If you will wait to choose if I solved your problem, I will keep working with you until it's resolved.________________________________________________________ Standard Disclaimer: There are links to non-Microsoft websites. The pages appear to be providing accurate, safe information. Watch out for ads on the sites that may advertise products frequently classified as a PUP (Potentially Unwanted Products). However, they come into errors upon attempting to install DirectX. I've done a great deal of looking into it, on this forum and others, and have yet to find anything that has helped me. I've attempted using the DirectX installer linked in so many help posts of similar issues, but to no avail. In the past couple days it had been giving me the apparently infamous "internal error" message, asking users to look at dxerror.log, however today it has stated that it is copying files, then claiming it has succeeded despite proof to the contrary. solutions: Hi GreedyLamb, I would suggest you perform the in-place upgrade. You may try following these steps. Check this article for detailed instructions. https://www.kapilarya.com/how-to-repair-windows...Thank you! Standard Disclaimer: There are links to non-Microsoft websites. The pages appear to be providing accurate, safe information. Watch out for ads on the sites that may advertise products frequently classified as a PUP (Potentially Unwanted Products). Thoroughly research any product advertised on the sites before you decide to download and install it.

windows.symptom: Annoying sounds        How do I eliminate piano sounds when moving cursor around on screen?
solutions: Start button > Settings app > System > Sound > Sound Control Panel > Sounds tab > Sound Scheme > Windows DefaultYou also need to ask yourself how the piano sounds got into your computer in the first place.

windows.symptom: Folder recovery in Windows 10 Mail        I had a folder named KEEPERS that had a lot of sub folders all containing emails that I was saving and because they all showed as containing nothing when I was using the Windows 10 Mail program I deleted the KEEPERS folder and the result was that it deleted everything that was in my account at my provider, ptd.net! Is there any way to restore this folder and all of its sub folders and their content?The missing folder is not in the deleted folder!Ron
solutions: Is the account set up to use POP or IMAP? If imap then it’ll have synced to the online account & deleted the folder, your only option is to contact your provider & hope they can assist you to recover it.If pop then there’s a chance it is still available via the webmail version of your account.Unfortunately if the folder is missing on the webmail version of your account then it’s gone for good.

That apparently is what happened since the folder and all of the sub folders were not present when I logged into my webmail online.  Just strange that there was no content showing when looking at the "KEEPER" folder via Windows 10 Mail!

If there is no content within the folder on webmail then ala it has been deleted permanently.If you’re using imap then deleting mails etc will reflect immediately on webmail as this is a direct connection to the mailbox, if you don’t want this to happen you should use pop/pop3 for the incoming server.
Do you require further help?
All was lost so no resolution to my issue.  Thanks for you input.

As I suspected, sorry it was the case. If you don’t have any further questions please feel free to mark one of the replies as the answer &/or rate my help: 1 star means you are very unsatisfied with my help and 5 stars means you are very satisfied with the help I gave you.

I’m sorry to see that you’ve marked my reply as not helpful when I gave you the honest answer. I understand you’re angry at deleting precious emails but that isn’t my fault.In future you should be more careful when deleting emails.

windows.symptom: num  lock        My num lock and the number keys (on the far right of the keyboard) do not work while on the internet. They work normally if not. I can not use the keys to include  them in an email. Need some help. By the way the number keys on the top of the keyboard work in both formats.
solutions: Hi rocking, My name is Marc, thanks for participating in the Microsoft Community, I'm an Independent Advisor and I'll be glad to help you today.Let's try to solve the problem by applying the following steps, they are official recommendations of Microsoft. Is it a built-in keyboard or USB keyboard?1.- Keyboard won't type numbers or will only type numbers https://www.thewindowsclub.com/keyboard-wont-ty...2.- Start with a clean boot in Windows, so we will know if the problem is being generated by a third-party program or driver, you also have the option of safe mode, both are error-proof starts, run and verify the results.https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/929135...3.- As an alternative, if necessary >> Use the On-Screen Keyboard (OSK) to type https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/10762/...Let me know if you have something else that I can help you with, I'd be happy to help.Happy holidays Regards, Marc M. Note: This is a non-Microsoft website. The page appears to be providing accurate, safe information. Watch out for ads on the site that may advertise products frequently classified as a PUP (Potentially Unwanted Products). Thoroughly research any product advertised on the site before you decide to download and install it.

windows.symptom: not enough space to reset        Tryinfg to resewt my computer and will not let me..
solutions: Hi Stacey. I'm Greg, an installation specialist, 10 year Windows MVP, and Volunteer Moderator here to help you.Are you referring to the Windows 10 Reset shown here: https://www.zdnet.com/article/windows-10-tip-re... /Reset will frequently fail for various reasons, an alternative is the in-place Repair Install which is an Upgrade over itself that reinstalls Windows while keeping your files, settings and apps in place. You can even customize it to Save Nothing which is the same as a Reset. I will give you steps to both free up space on smaller drives and perform version Updates and Repair Upgrade on them manually by the most stable method that requires much less space than Windows Update.First here are tips for managing smaller drives including the 32-gb SSD which they should have never allowed Windows 10 be installed upon:https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/...https://www.pcworld.com/article/3040404/windows...https://www.groovypost.com/howto/maximize-stora...As more space becomes needed, you can move your Desktop, Documents and Pictures folders to another internet hard drive you have or install, or into OneDrive and then set them to On Demand so they reside in the cloud and only have download links on the PC:https://www.tenforums.com/tutorials/116029-turn...https://www.pcworld.com/article/3233488/windows...You can also offload User folders (Documents, Music, Pictures, etc) to another drive you can install on the same PC (even in the DVD drive bay) as shown in this tutorial, which will not affect speed if C is on an SSD and the other drive is not:https://www.tenforums.com/tutorials/1964-move-u.... I would not move program files or speed will be affected. You could also install a larger SSD/HDD.This should make enough space to install Windows Updates or even the Reset. But for now I'd focus on the latest Version update since successfully installing it will bring along all Windows Updates and also resolves almost all other problems since it reinstalls Windows keeping your files and programs in place.Install the Media Creation Tool on another PC to create bootable media or download the ISO to stick or disk, transfer it back to the target PC to open the media or click to mount the ISO, right click Setup file to Run as Administrator. This avoids needing the space to download the Upgrade and it's staging files. http://windows.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-10/m... Another option is to do the the best possible Clean Install in this link which will stay that way as long as you stick with the tools and methods given, has zero reported problems, and is better than any amount of money could buy:http://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wiki.... This will give you back all but 15gb of the drive. There is also an automated Fresh Start that reinstalls WIndows while shedding corrupting factory bloatware, saves your files, but doesn't clear the drive to get it cleanest:https://www.howtogeek.com/265054/how-to-easily-... You can also turn off or block Updates if they are bothering you. There are ways to block Updates here: https://www.howtogeek.com/223864/how-to-uninsta... If you want you can set a Metered Connection per the above tutorial, then when ready turn it off to install Updates. You can even wait until the twice-yearly Version Updates to run manually from Media Creation Tool which is a more stable method than Windows Update and includes all previous updates rolled into it. http://windows.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-10/m... I hope this helps. Feel free to ask back any questions and let us know how it goes. The pages appear to be providing accurate, safe information. Watch out for ads on the sites that may advertise products frequently classified as a PUP (Potentially Unwanted Products).
